sp.p: Will be a great improvement to you, and quite right for me. Teaſe—teaſe, and tame, is a rule without exception from the keeper of the lions to the teacher of a piping bulfinch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: But you hard hearted thing, will you name any object for his jealouſy?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: No, keep him there in the dark— Always keep your creature in the dark—That's another ſecret of taming—Don't be grave, Lady Emily.— whoſe attention is fixed on Miſs Alton Your brother's purgatory ſhall be ſhort, and I'll take the reconciliation ſcene upon myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: endeavouring to recover herſelf. I cannot but pity him; eſpecially as I am ſure, that do what you will, he will always regard you with the ſame eyes. And ſo, my ſweet ſiſter, I leave him to your mercy, and to that of your repreſentative, whoſe diſpoſition, if I have any judgment, is ill ſuited to a taſk of ſeverity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Dear Lady Emily carry me away with you. When a lover is coming, it ſhall never be ſaid I am in the way.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: I am at your orders looking at Miſs Alton. aſideſ What a ſuſpenſe am I to ſuffer? a moment more and I ſhall betray myſelf—adieu, Miſs Alſcrip.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Call Lady Emily's ſervants.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: You ſha'n't ſtir—remember nimini—primini. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Coming back and ſqueezing Miſs Alſcrip's hand, in a half whiſper. She'd give her eyes to be like you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Now for it, Miſs Alton—Only remember that you are doubling me the woman he adores.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I am quite incapable of executing you orders to your ſatisfaction. The utmoſt I can undertake is a ſhort meſſage.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Never fear. Knock at the door. There he comes—Step aſide and I'll give you your very words. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lord Gayville, conducted by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: So, now to get thorough this piece of drudgery. There's a meanneſs in my proceeding, and my compunction is juſt. Oh, the dear loſt poſſeſſor of my heart! loſt, irrecoverably loſt!

div.stage: Enter Miſs Alton from the bottom of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: A pretty employment I am ſent upon.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: to himſelf Could ſhe but know the ſacrifice I am ready to make?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: to herſelf. The very picture of a lover, if abſence of mind marks one. It is unpleaſant for me to interrupt a man I never ſaw, but I ſhall deliver my meſſage very conciſely.— My Lord.—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: turning. Madam. both ſtart and ſtand in ſurprize Aſtoniſhment! Miſs Alton! my charming fugitive!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: How! Mr. Heartly—Lord Gayville!

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: My joy and my ſurprize are alike unutterable. But I conjure you, Madam, tell me by what ſtrange circumſtance do I meet you here?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: aſide Now aſſiſt me, honeſt pride!— aſſiſt me reſentment.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: You ſpoke to me — Did you know me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: No otherwiſe, my Lord, than as Miſs Alſcrip's lover. I had a meſſage from her to your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Madam, in what capacity?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: In one, my Lord, not very much above the claſs of a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Impoſſible, ſure!— It is to place the brilliant below the foil—to make the inimitable work of nature ſecondary to art and defect.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: It is to take refuge in a ſituation that offers me ſecurity againſt ſuſpicious obligation; againſt vile deſign; againſt the attempts of a ſeducer—It is to exerciſe the patience, that the will, and perhaps the favor of heaven, meant to try.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Cruel, cruel to yourſelf and me— Could I have had a happineſs like that of aſſiſting you againſt the injuſtice of fortune—and when to be thus degraded was the alternative.—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: My Lord, it is fit I ſhould be explicit. Reflect upon the language you have held to me; view the character in which you preſent yourſelf to this family; and then pronounce in whoſe breaſt we muſt look for a ſenſe of degradation.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: In mine, and mine alone. I confeſs it—Hear nevertheleſs my defence—My actions are all the reſult of love. And culpable as I may ſeem, my conſcience does not reproach me with—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, I readily believe you—You are above its reproaches — Qualities that are infamous and fatal, in one claſs of life, create applauſe and conſcientious ſatisfaction in another.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Infamous and fatal qualiites! What means my lovely accuſer?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: That to ſteal or ſtab is death in common life: but when one of your lordſhip's degree ſets his hard heart upon the deſtruction of a woman, how glorious is his ſucceſs! How conſummate his triumph! When he can follow the theft of her affections by the murder of her honour.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I wonder how it goes on.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Exalted! Adorable woman!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Adorable! Aye, I thought how 'twou'd be!

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Hear me! I conjure you—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Not a word, if ſhe knows her buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: My Lord! I have heard too much.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Brava! I cou'd not have play'd it better myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Oh! Sill more charming than ſevere. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Humph! I hope he means me though.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: The character in which you ſee me here, makes me appear more odious to myſelf, if poſſible, than I am to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: behind By all that's treacherous I doubt it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: Deſiſt my Lord — Miſs Alſcrip has a claim.—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Aye, now for it.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p:
By heav'n ſhe is my averſion. It is my family on whom I am dependant that has betray'd me into theſe curſed addreſſes—Accept
my contrition—pity a wretch ſtruggling with the complicated torments of paſſion, ſhame, penitence and deſpair.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: comes forward all ſtand confuſed I never ſaw a part better doubled in my life!

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Confuſion! What a light do I appear in to them both. How ſhall I redeem myſelf, even in my own opinion?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: looking at Lord Gayville. Expreſſive dignity looking at Miſs Alton Sweet ſimplicity! Amiable diffidence!—She ſhould execute my commands moſt aukwardly.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: aſide There is but one way.— to Miſs Alſcrip. Madam, your ſudden entrance has effected a diſcovery which with ſhame I confeſs ought to have been made before — The lady who ſtands there is in poſſeſſion of my heart. If it is a crime to adore her, I am the moſt guilty wretch on earth—pardon me if you can; my ſincerity is painful to me—But in this criſis it is the only atonement I can offer. Bows and exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: after a pauſe. Admirable!—Perf • ct! The moſt finiſh'd declaration I am convinc'd, that ever was made from beggarly nobility to the woman who was to make his fortune—the Lady who ſtands there—the lady—Madam—I am in patient expectation for the ſincerity of your ladyſhip's atonement.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: I am confounded at the ſtrange occurrences that have happen'd; but be aſſured you ſee in me an innocent, and moſt unwilling rival.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p:
Rival! Better and better!—You— you give me uneaſineſs! You moppet—you coquet of the ſide table to catch the gawkey heir of the family, when he comes from ſchool at Chriſtmas—You—you—you vile ſeducer of my good
old, honour'd father! cries in a paſſion again What, is my lady dumb? Huſſey? Have you the inſolence to hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: Madam, I juſt now offer'd to juſtify this ſcene; I thought it the part of duty to myſelf, and reſpect to you. But your behaviour has now left but one ſentiment upon my mind.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: And what is that, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p: With pointed expreſſion Scorn.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Was there ever any thing like this before — and to a woman of my fortune— I to be robb'd of a lover—and that a poor Lord too—I'll have the act reviv'd againſt witchcraft; I'll have the minx tried—I'll—I'll—I'll verify the proverb of the tragedy—
Hell has no fury like a woman ſcorn'd. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Alſcrip's room of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Upon all theſe matters, Mr. Alſcrip, I am authorized by my client, Sir Clement Flint, to agree. There remains nothing but your favouring me with the inſpection of the Charlton title deeds, and your daughter's ſettlements may be engroſſed.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: I cannot conceive, my friend Rightly, any ſuch inſpection to be requiſite. Have not I been in conſtant quiet poſſeſſion?

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Sir Clement inſiſts upon it.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: A client inſiſt! and you an old practitioner, ſuffer ſuch a demur to your infallibility!— Ah! in my practice I had the ſure means of diſappointing ſuch dabblers and divers into their own caſes.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: How, pray?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: I read his writings to him myſelf— I was the beſt reader in Chancery-lane for ſetting the underſtanding at defiance—Drew breath but once in a quarter of an hour, always in the wrong place, and made a ſingle ſentence of ſix ſkins of parchment—Shall I give you a ſpecimen?

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Smiling I have no doubt of your talent.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Then return to Sir Clement, and follow my example.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: No, Mr. Alſcrip, tho' I acknowledge your ſkill, I do not ſubſcribe to your doctrine. The Engliſh law is the fineſt ſyſtem of ethics, as well as government, that ever the world produced, and it cannot be too generally underſtood.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Law underſtood! Zounds! wou'd you deſtroy the profeſſion?

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: No, I wou'd raiſe it. Had every man of ſenſe the knowledge of the theory, to which he is competent; the practice wou'd revert to the purity of its inſtitution, maintain the rights, and not promote the knavery of mankind.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: aſide Plaguy odd maxims.—Sure he means to try me.— to him Brother Rightly, we know the world, and are alone—I have lock'd the door in a half whiſper.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: A very uſeleſs precaution. I have not a principle nor a proceeding that I wou'd not proclaim at Charing-croſs.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: aſide No! then I'll pronounce you the moſt ſilly, or the moſt impudent fellow of the fraternity.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p:
But where are theſe writings? You can have no difficulty in laying your hand upon them,
for I perceive you keep things in a diſtinguiſh'd regularity.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Yes, I have diſtinct repoſitories for all papers, and eſpecially title deeds—Some in drawers— Some in cloſets— aſide and a few under ground.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: rattling at the door. What makes you lock the door, Sir? I muſt ſpeak to you this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: One moment child, and I'll be ready for you. Turning again to Rightly as to diſſuade him.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Still rattling the door. Don't tell me of moments—let me in.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Wheugh! What impatient devil poſſeſſes the girl—Stay a moment I tell you— Turns again to Rightly.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: cooly. If the thoughts of the wedding-day makes any part of the young Lady's impatience, you take a bad way, Mr. Alſcrip, to ſatisfy it; for I tell you plainly our buſineſs cannot be compleated till I ſee theſe writings.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: aſide Confound the old hound—how he ſticks to his ſcent.

div.stage: Miſs Alſcrip, ſtill at the door.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: I am coming I tell you. Opens a bureau in a confuſed hurry ſhuffles papers about, puts one into Rightly's hand. There, if this whim muſt be indulged, ſtep into the next room — You who know the material parts of a parchment lie in a nutſhell, will look it over in ten minutes. Puts him into another room.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I won't wait another inſtant whatever you are about—Let me in.—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: opening the door. Sex, and vehemence! What is the matter now?

stage.hi: Enter Miſs Alſcrip, in the moſt violent emotion.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: So, Sir; yes, Sir; you have done finely by me indeed, you are a pattern for fathers—a precious match you had provided.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: running on I that with 50,000 independant pounds left myſelf in a father's hands— a thing unheard of, and waited for a huſband with unparalleled patience till I was of age—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: following him about. I that at fourteen might have married a French Marquis, my governeſs told me he was—for all he was her brother—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Gad a mercy, governeſs—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: And as for commoners, had not I the choice of the market? And the handſome Iriſh Colonel at Bath, that had carried off ſix heireſſes before, for himſelf and friends, and wou'd have found his way to Gretna-green blindfold!

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: aſide Gad I wiſh you were there now with all my heart—What the devil is at the bottom of all this?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Why Lord Gayville is at the bottom—And your huſſey that you were ſo ſweet upon this morning, is at the bottom! a treacherous minx!—I ſent her only for a little innocent diverſion as my double—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Your what?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Why my double, to vex him.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p:
Double! this is the moſt uſeleſs attendant you have had yet.—Gad I'll ſtart you
ſingle handed in the art of vexation againſt any ten women in England.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I caught them, juſt as I did you.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Is that all? Gad I don't ſee much in that.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Not much? what, a woman of my fortune and accompliſhments turn'd off—rejected—renounc'd—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: How! renounc'd? has he broke the contract!—Will you prove he has broke the contract?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Aye. Now my dear papa, you take a tone that becomes you; now the blood of the Alſcrip's riſes;—riſes, as it ought; you mean to fight him directly, don't you?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Oh yes, I'm his man—I'll ſhew you a lawyer's challenge, ſticks and ſtaves, guns, ſwords, daggers, poinards, knives, ſciſſars and bodkins. I'll put more weapons into a bit of paper, ſix inches ſquare than wou'd ſtock the armory of the tower.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Piſtols!—Don't talk to me of any thing but piſtols,—my dear papa, who ſhall be your ſecond?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: I'll have two — John Doe, and Richard Roe—as pretty fellows as any in England to ſee fair play, and as us'd to the differences of good company.—They ſhall greet him with their fieri facias—ſo don't be caſt down, Molly, I'll anſwer for damages to indemnify our loſs of temper and reputation—he ſhall have a fi-fa before to-morrow night.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p:
Fiery faces and damages—What does your Weſtminſter-hall gibberiſh mean?— Are a woman's feelings to be ſatisfied with a
fie-fa—you old inſenſible—you have no ſenſe of family honour—no tender affections.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Gad you have enough for us both, when you want your father to be ſhot through the head—but ſtand out of the way, here's a ſpecies of family honour more neceſſary to be taken care of—If we were to go to law, this wou'd be a precious ſet off againſt us. Takes up the deed as if to lock it up This—why what the devil—I hope I don't ſee clear—Curſe and confuſion, I have given the wrong one—Here's fine work—Here's a blunder—Here's the effect of a woman's impetuoſity.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Lord, what a fuſs you are in; what is in the old trumpery ſcroll?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Plague and parchment, old Rightly will find what's in it, if I don't interrupt him— Mr. Rightly—Mr. Rightly—Mr. Rightly— going to the door Rightly went out at.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Rightly is gone.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Gone! whither?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Home, I believe, Sir—He came out at the door into the hall, and bade me tell your honor you might depend upon his reading over the deed with particular care.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Fire, and fury, my hat and cane— Exit Servant. Here, my hat and cane ſtamps about.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Sir, I expect, before you come home—

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p:
Death and devils, expect to be ruin'd —this comes of liſt'ning to you—The ſex hold
the power of miſchief by preſcription—Zounds —Miſchief—Miſchief—is the common law of womankind. Exit in a rage.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Mercy on us—I never ſaw him more provok'd, even when my mother was alive.

div.head: SCENE I. Alſcrip's Room.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: QUE diable vent dire tout ca—vat devil, all dis mean?—Monſieur Alſcrip enrage'—Madamoiſelle Alſcrip fly about like de dancing fury at de Opera—My littel muſicienne, ſhut up, and in de abſence of Madame, I keep de key of de littel Baſtille—By gad, I vou'd rader have de cuſtody of my pretty priſoniere than the whole college of cardinals—but vat have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.p: ſpeaking to a ſervant Mr. Alſcrip not at home, no matter—we'll wait his return— The French Valet de Chambre to Clifford—It may be of uſe to make acquaintance with him— Monſieur, how do you like this country?

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: Ver good contree Sire, by and bye— when you grow a little more poor.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Is that a Pariſian rule for improvement?

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and we help you to follow our example—In good times you hang, and you drown—In bad time you vill be like us.—Alway poor—alway gay—forget your politics— laugh at your grievances—take your ſnuff, vive la diſſipation,—ver good country.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p:
Thanks for your kind advice, Monſieur, you Frenchmen are ſo obliging, and ſo communicative to ſtrangers—I hear there is a
young lady come into this family—we don't exactly know in what capacity—could not you contrive that ſhe ſhou'd paſs through this room— or—

sp.speaker: Chignon
sp.p: aſide. By gar here be one more old rake after de littel muſicienne.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Only for curioſity,—we never ſaw her, and have particular reaſons— gives money.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: Ma foi, your reaſons be ver expreſſive aſide—but vat devil ſhall I do—open de cage of my little Roſignol—my pretty nightingale—no. Chignon—no— looking out ah, hah! La Tiffany —Now for de politique—begar I undertake your buſineſs—and make you de dupe of de performance. Exit with a ſign to Sir Clement.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: So—Clifford—There goes as diſintereſted a fellow now as any in Europe.—But hark you—Can you yet gueſs the purpoſe for which I brought you here?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I profeſs, Sir, I am in the dark. If it concerns Lord Gayville's ſecret.—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Namely, that I have diſcovered, without your aſſiſtance, that this Dulcinea has ſtarted up in the ſhape of Miſs Alſcrip's muſical companion—Her name is Alton, leering I tell it you, becauſe I am ſure you did not know it—or if you had—a friend's ſecret ought to be ſacred; and to keep it from the only perſon, who by knowing it cou'd ſave him from deſtruction, would be a new exerciſe of your virtue.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Sir, you will not know me.—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Tut, tut, don't do me ſuch injuſtice — Come, all delicacy being over by my having made the diſcovery, will you talk to this girl?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: For what end, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: If you ſtate yourſelf as Lord Gayville's friend, ſhe will converſe with you more readily, than ſhe wou'd with me—Try her— find out what ſhe is really at—If ſhe proves an impoſtor of the refined artifice I ſuſpect, that puts on humility to veil her purpoſe, and chaſtity to effect it—leave her to me—if ſhe has no hold upon him but her perſon, I ſhall be eaſy.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Sir, let my compliance convince you how much I wiſh to oblige you. If I can get a ſight of this wonder, I promiſe to give you my faithful opinion of my friend's danger.

div.stage: Enter Chignon and makes a ſign to Sir Clement, that the perſon he enquir'd after is coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Leave her with this gentleman— Come Monſieur, you ſhall ſhew me the new room.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: aſide. Vid dis gentleman—Vid all my heart—La Tiffany vill anſwer his purpoſe, and mine too. Exit. Clifford is looking at the furniture of the room.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: What does the Frenchman mean by gentlemen wanting me, and his gibberiſh of making ſoft eyes—I hope I know the exerciſe of my eyes without his inſtruction — hah! I vow, a clever looking man.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: ſeeing Tiffany. A good ſmart girl; but not altogether quaker-like in her apparel, nor does her air quite anſwer my conception of a goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: aſide. How he examines me! ſo much the better—I ſhall loſe nothing by that, I believe.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Faith a pretty attracting countenance —but for that apprehenſive and timid look— that awe impreſſing modeſty, my friend ſo forcibly deſcrib'd.

div.stage: Tiffany adjuſts herſelf and pulls up.

sp.speaker: Clifford
sp.p: aſide There is no judging of that wonderful ſex by rational rules—Her ſilence marks diffidence; deuce take me if I know how to begin for fear of offending her reſerve.

sp.speaker: Tiffany
sp.p: aſide. I have been told pertneſs became me—I'll try, I'm reſolved. to him I hear, Sir, you had ſomething to ſay to a young perſon of this houſe—that—that— looking down at the ſame time archly I cou'd not but take the deſcription to myſelf—I am ready to hear any thing a gentleman has to ſay.

sp.speaker: Clifford
sp.p: aſide. Thank my ſtars, my ſcruples are relieved.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: Am I miſtaken, Sir? Pray whom was you enquiring after.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Oh! certainly you, my pretty ſtranger. A friend of mine has been robbed of his heart, and I ſee the felony in your looks.

sp.speaker: Tiffany
sp.p: ſimpering and coquetting. Lord, Sir, if I had ſuſpected you had come with a ſearch warrant for hearts, I wou'd have been more upon my guard.

sp.speaker: Clifford
sp.p: chucking her under the chin. Will you confeſs, or muſt I arreſt you?

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: Innocent, Sir, in fact, but not quite ſo in inclination—I hope your own is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: And were it not, my ſmart unconſcionable, would you run away with that alſo.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p:
Oh yes, and an hundred more; and melt them all down together as the Jews do ſtolen goods
to prevent their being reclaim'd—Gold, ſilver and lead; pray, Sir of what metal may your's be?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: aſide Aſtoniſhing! Have I hit upon the moment when her fancy outruns her art! — Or has it been Gayville's amuſement to deſcribe her by contraries? And are you really the young Lady that is the companion of Miſs Alſcrip, that makes ſuch conqueſts at firſt ſight.—

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: Sir, if you mean the young Lady who has been named, however undeſervedly, the flower of this family; that appears ſometimes at theſe windows; and to be ſure has been followed home by gentlemen againſt her inclinations—Sir, you are not miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: aſide It has been Gayville's madneſs or amuſement then to deſcribe her by contraries.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you are not offended, I wou'd not be impertinent, tho' I am not ſo taſteleſs as to ſhy.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Offended, my dear? I am quite charm'd I aſſure you. You are juſt what I did not expect, but wiſhed to find you. You had been repreſented to me ſo improperly.—

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: with pertneſs. Repreſented improperly! Pray, Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: To rejoice in my miſtake I promiſe you—Nay, and to ſet my friend right in his opinion, and ſo without further ſhyneſs on either part, let us be free upon the ſubject I had to talk over with you. You ſurely are not looking to laſting connections.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: with airs. Sir, I don't underſtand you—I am not what you ſuppoſe, I aſſure you— Connections indeed—I ſhould never have thought of that—my character — my behaviour, connexions, I don't know what the word ſignifies.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: without Clifford—are you ready?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I am at your orders, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: aſide Deuce take this interruption!

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: without I ſhall not wait for Mr. Alſcrip any longer.

sp.speaker: Tiffany.
sp.p: aſide Lud, lud, he gives me no time to come round again. Runs up to him confuſedly. It's very true, Sir, I wou'd not do ſuch a thing for the world, but you are a man of honour, and I am ſure wou'd not give bad advice to a poor girl who is but a novice—and ſo, Sir. Hears Sir Clement entering. Put your propoſal in writing and you may depend on having an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Well, Clifford, what do you think of her?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Make yourſelf perfectly eaſy, Sir: This girl when known can make no impreſſion on Lord Gayville's mind; and I doubt not but a ſilk gown and a lottery ticket, had they been offer'd as an ultimatum, wou'd have purchaſed her perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: With a dry ſneer. Don't you ſometimes, Clifford, form erroneous opinions of peoples' pretenſions? Intereſt and fooliſh paſſion inſpire ſtrange notions—as one or the other prevails, we are brought to look ſo low, or ſo high—

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: With emotion. That we are compell'd to call reaſon and honour to our aid—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: And then—

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: We loſe the intemperance of our inclinations in the ſenſe of what is right.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: aſide Sententious impoſtor! to him But to the point.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd pleaſe you, if I cou'd—I am thinking of a ſcheme to reſtore Lord Gayville to his ſenſes, without violence or injury to any one of the parties.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Why the wench being cut ſhort of marketing by word of mouth (which ſhe was doing in all due form when you came in) deſired me to write propoſals. I am inclined to do ſo. We will ſhew the anſwer to Lord Gayville, and depend upon it, there will be character enough diſplay'd to cure him of the ſentimental part of his attachment.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: I like your idea—Sit down and put it into execution immediately— Clifford writes.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: to himſelf. He is quick at invention—has a pretty turn at profeſſion—A proud and peremptory ſhew of honour that wou'd overpower prejudices—Thank heaven, my opinions of knavery are convictions.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Writing. I am ſorry to detain you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p:
Looking at the furniture. Oh! I am amuſing myſelf better than you think—Indulging an edifying contemplation among the tombs of departed eſtates— Looking round the furniture, viz: cloſets that ſhew old writings tied up, ſhelves with boxes labelled mortgages, leaſe and releaſe, &c. What mouldered ſkins that will never ſee day-light again, and that with a good herald wou'd vie with Weſtminſter-abbey in holiday entertainment. For inſtance now, what have we here?—Hah! The laſt remains of Fatland priory— Once of great monaſtic importance: A proverb of pride, ſloth, and hypocriſy. After the reformation the ſeat of old Engliſh hoſpitality and benevolence
—In the preſent century, altered, adorned, pull'd down, and the materials ſold by auction.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Edifying indeed, Sir; your comments are not loſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Here lie undiſturbed in duſt, the relicks of Court-baron caſtle, granted at the conqueſt to the family of Loftimount. The laſt of this ancient race having won twenty-ſeven king's plates, and repreſented the county in ſix parliaments, after many ſtruggles died of the piſtol fever—a diſconſolate annuitant inſcribed this box to his memory.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! Riſing. I am quite concern'd to interrupt you, Sir, but you ſhall hear my letter, reads.
You have captivated a young man of rank and fortune, but you are diſcover'd, and his ruin and yours wou'd be the conſequence of purſuing any deſigns, that cou'd impede his propoſed marriage with Miſs Alſcrip—Throw yourſelf upon the generoſity of his family, and your fortune's made — Send your anſwer (and let it be immediate) to me at Sir Clement Flint's houſe—Yours, &c. &c. —
HENRY CLIFFORD.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: It will do very well, our French friend is the man to deliver it, and to bring the anſwer. I am going home, you'll overtake me.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Sealing the letter. You come apropos. Monſieur gives the letter with an air of myſtery. Have the goodneſs to put this letter into Miſs Alton's own hands.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: to himſelf. Madamoiſelle Alton▪ Peſte! My trick has not paſſed.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: To Miſs Alton by herſelf—I am in all the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: to himſelf. Devil take Tiffany for making you ſo wiſe.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: And you ſerve your Lady, when you ſerve me with Miſs Alton—Monſieur, an anſwer as quick as poſſible—You will find me at Sir Clement Flint's—it is only in the next ſtreet—and— you underſtand me— ſhaking his purſe. Alerte, Monſieur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: Underſtand you—Oui! da you talk de language univerſal imitating his ſhaking the purſe I'entre vois, I begin to ſee ſomething—By gad I vill give de letter, and try de inclination of Mademoiſelle la Muſicienne—if dis be de duette ſhe vill play, it take her out of the vay of Alſcrip, of Gayville, and of myſelf alſo—Vo la le malheur— there—de misfortune—eh bien—when love and intereſt come acroſs—alway prefer de intereſt for to-day and take de chance of de love to-morrow— dat is de humour of France. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Clement Flint's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Lord Gayville and Sir Clement.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayvile.
sp.p: I am reſolved to ſee Miſs Alſcrip, no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: And I hope you are prepared with arguments to juſtify the cauſe of this breach, to me, and to the world.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p:
For my reconciliation with you I hope your former partiality will return to my aid; and as for the world I deſpiſe it. The multitude look at happineſs thro' the falſe glare of
wealth and pomp: I have diſcovered it, tho' yet at a diſtance, thorough the only true medium, that of mutual affection.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: No common place book formed from a whole library of plays and novels could furniſh a better ſentence. Your folly wou'd ſhame a ſchool boy — even of the laſt age—In the preſent he learns the world with his grammar, and gets a juſt notion of the worthleſsneſs of the other ſex before he is of an age to be duped by their attractions.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Sir, your prejudices.—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: My prejudices?— will you appeal to Clifford—here he comes—your friend—your

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: And will Clifford, condemn the choice of the heart?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Never, my lord, when juſtly placed—In the caſe I perceive you are arguing, I am ready to bluſh for you—nay, don't look grave—I am acquainted with your inchantreſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: You acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Yes, and if I don't deceive myſelf, ſhall make her break her own ſpell. I am in correſpondence with her.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: You in correſpondence with Miſs Alton!—when? where? What am I to think of this?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: My dear Lord, that ſhe is the moſt errant coquette, the moſt accompliſhed jilt, the moſt ready trafficker of her charms—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Phrenzy and profanation—Such dignity of virtue, ſuch chaſtity of ſentiment—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Phrenzy indeed! You have formed a creature of imagination, and like a true Quixote think it real; you have talked to her of dignity, of virtue and chaſtity, of ſentiment, till you have taught her a lure ſhe never dreamt of—Had you treated her at firſt as I did, ſhe wou'd have put a card into your hand to inform you of her lodging.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Clifford, what has betray'd you into calumny ſo unwarrantable and deſpicable?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Come, Gayville, I'll be plain with you, you have ſillily let the girl raiſe her price upon you—but if nothing elſe will ſatisfy you, e'en pay it, and have done with her.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Sir, her price is an unadulterated heart: I am afraid we cannot pay it betwixt us.

stage.stage: delivers a letter to Clifford apart.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: Alerte, Monſieure, I repete your word—Madamoiſelle Alton, be all your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Come, Clifford, the contents: his Lordſhip braves the trial.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: What is this mighty ſcheme? and what is that paper to diſcover?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: breaking open the letter Your Lordſhip ſhall be informed word for word. Upon firſt ſight of the contents he ſhews the utmoſt emotion Amazement! do I dream! can it be? who wrote this letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Oh! ſpeak out Monſieur, we are all friends.

sp.speaker: Chignon.
sp.p: De true Madamoiſelle Alton to whom you charge me to give your letter—ſhe open it— ſhe turn pale—den red—den confuſe—den kiſſe your name—den write, and bid me fly.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Confuſion, on confuſion, what does all this mean? explain.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me, I am diſconſerted—confounded—thunder-ſtruck—This letter is indeed of a different nature, from that I expected—I am more intereſted in Miſs Alton's fate, than your Lordſhip—my perplexity is not to be endur'd; friend, come with me inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Myſtery, and torture! what am I to collect from this? He intereſted in the fate of Miſs Alton? he her former acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Why not—and her dupe alſo?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Is Mr. Clifford gone, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: impatiently Who wants him?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A chairman with a letter, he will not deliver to a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Call the fellow in. Exit Servant. Who knows but he may help us in our difficulties.

div.stage: Chairman brought in with a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: ſtill impatiently Whom did you bring that letter from?

sp.speaker: Chairman.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honor, I don't know; paſſing through the ſquare, a ſaſh flew up, and down came this letter and half a crown upon my head. It could not have fallen better, there's not a fellow in town more expert than I am at private buſineſs—So I reſolved to deliver it ſafely—Is your honor's name Clifford?

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: No indeed, friend, I am not ſo happy a man.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p:
aſide That letter muſt not be loſt though. Here, my friend—I'll take charge of
your letter. takes the letter Something for your pains.

sp.speaker: Chairman.
sp.p: God bleſs your honor, and if you want to ſend an anſwer, my number is forty ſeven in Bond-ſtreet—your honor, I am known by the name of ſecret Tom. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: What is the uſe of this deceit? ſtrong as my ſuſpicion is, a ſeal muſt be ſacred.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Our circumſtances make an exception to your rule: when there is treaſon in the ſtate, wax gives way. takes the letter, opens and reads it. Faith this is beyond my expectation—tho' the myſtery is unfathomable, the aptneſs of it to my purpoſe is admirable—Gayville—I wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Of conviction! if this is not plain! only hear reads "ſince my confuſed lines of a few minutes paſt, my perplexities redouble upon my ſpirits—I am in momentary apprehenſion of further inſult from the Alſcrip family; I am ſtill more anxious to avoid Lord Gayville" pauſes and looks at Lord Gayville: "do not ſuſpect my ſincerity—I have not a thought of him that ought to diſturb you."—Here ſhe is Gayville, look at her, through the true medium of mutual affection—"I have not a thought of him that ought to diſturb you"—Fly to me, ſecure me, my deareſt Henry.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Deareſt Henry!

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: reads on"Deareſt Henry—In this call, the danger of your Harriet unites with the impatience of her affection."

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Hell, and fury! this muſt be ſome trick, ſome forgery ſnatches the letter. No, by all that's perfidious it is that exquiſite hand that baffles imitation.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: All, regular, ſtrict, undeviating modern morals—common property is the firſt principle of friendſhip; your horſe, your houſe, your purſe, your miſtreſs—nay, your wife wou'd be a better example ſtill of the doctrine of this generous age. Bleſs fortune, Gayville, that has brought the fidelity of your friend and your girl to the teſt at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Sir, I am not in a humour for any ſpleen but my own. What can this mean?— It muſt have been a ſecret attachment for years— but then the avowal of a correſpondence and the confuſion at receiving it—his coldneſs in traducing her; the paſſionate intereſt he expreſs'd in her fate; the conviction of his ſecond letter—It is all delirium. I'll ſearch the matter to the bottom, tho' I go to Clifford's heart for it. Exit in great anger.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: I'll after the precious fellow too— He is a rogue above my hopes, and the intricacy of his ſnares excite my curioſity. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Lady Emily's Apartment.
div.p: It will not do. My eyes may run over a thouſand ſubjects, but my thoughts centre in one. Ah! that ſigh! that ſigh from the fair ſufferer this morning—I have found it echo in my own heart ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Blandiſh.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Pooh! did you ſay I was at home?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip gave no orders to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p:
Shew him in. Exit Servant. I muſt take up my air of levity again—It is the
only humour for a fellow who I ſometimes allow to entertain me, but who never can get my eſteem. I have more calls upon my affectation this unlucky day, than my real diſpoſition would execute in a long life.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Blandiſh, I am horridly peeviſh; have you any thing diverting in news or flattery?

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: In the latter, Madam, nothing. My admiration has all the dullneſs of truth: but ſhew me what you think a flaw, and I'll try without flattery to convince you it is a beauty.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Tolerably expreſs'd—but the idea of a faultleſs woman is falſe in point of encomium, ſhe wou'd be reſpectable, aweful, and unattracting. Odd as it may ſeem, a woman, to charm, requires a little daſh of harmleſs imperfection. I know I've a thouſand amiable faults that I wou'd not part with for the world. So try again: Something more new and refined.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: Examine my heart, Lady Emily, and you will find both: The novelty of diſintereſted paſſion, and refinement acquired by the ſtudy of you.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Rather better: but that does not pleaſe me much; the leſs, perhaps, as it is rather out of your way, and more in that of my friend your ſiſter, who, I obſerve, always put a compliment in full view—Yours generally come more forcibly, by affording us the pleaſure of finding them out—It is the excellency of a brilliant to play in the dark.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p:
Allow yourſelf to be the brilliant and attend to another alluſion. With trembling ambition,
I confeſs, that not content with admiring the jewel, I would wear it.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Wear it?

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: As an appendage to my heart—Conſcious of it's value, proud of its diſplay, and devoted to its preſervation.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Riddles, Mr. Blandiſh—but ſo let them remain—I aſſure you this hour is very inauſpicious for explanation.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: I fear ſo. For in an hour, when Clifford proves treacherous, who can eſcape ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Clifford? for what purpoſe is he introduced in this converſation?

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: You aſk'd me for intelligence, the lateſt is, that Clifford has been detected in a clandeſtine intercourſe with the object of Lord Gayville's ſecret paſſion; that he has betray'd the confidence of his friend and patron, and actually carried her off. aſide Which Gayville knows by this time with all its aggravations, or Prompt has not been as active as he us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p: with emotion. Blandiſh, this is a poor project. Clifford treacherous to his friend! You might as ſoon make me believe Gayville diſpaſſionate, my uncle charitable, or you ingenuous.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: His conduct does not reſt upon opinion, but proof; and when you know it you muſt think of him with averſion.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Muſt I? Then don't let me hear a word more—I have averſions enough already— peeviſhly.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: It is impoſſible you can apply that word to one whoſe only offence is to adore you. kiſſes her hand.

sp.speaker: Clifford
sp.p: aſide ſurprized. Blandiſh ſo favour'd?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p: aſide. Perverſe accident: what miſtakes now will he make!

sp.speaker: Blandiſh
sp.p: aſide. The enemy has ſurprized me— but the only remedy in ſuch emergencies, is to ſhew a good countenance.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I fear I have been guilty of an unpardonable intruſion.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: Mr. Clifford never can intrude, but though you had not come ſo apropos yourſelf— Lady Emily will bear teſtimony, I have not ſpared my pains to remove any prejudices ſhe might have entertained.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Had you not better repeat in your own words, Mr. Blandiſh, all the obliging things you have ſaid of this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: It is not neceſſary, Madam—If without robbing you of moments that I perceive are precious—

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I might obtain a ſhort audience, looking at Blandiſh.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh
sp.p: aſide. He's deviliſh impudent—but he cannot ſoon get over facts, and I'll take care the conference ſhall not be long. To Lady Emily —Lady Emily; hear Mr. Clifford, and judge if I have miſrepreſented him— to Clifford When you want a friend you know where to find him.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: This is an interview, Mr. Clifford, that I deſire not to be underſtood to have authoriſed. It is not to me, you are accountable for your actions—I have no perſonal intereſt in them.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I know it too well.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p: peeviſhly. Do not run away with the notion neither, that I am therefore intereſted in any other perſon's — You have among you, vex'd, and diſconcerted me, but there is not a grain of partiality in all my embarraſſment—if you have any eyes you may ſee there is not.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Happy Blandiſh, your triumph is evident.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Blandiſh, the odious creature— He is my abhorrence — You are hardly worſe yourſelf in my bad opinion, tho' you have done ſo much more to deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: How cruel are the circumſtances that compel me to leave you under theſe impreſſions —nay more—at ſuch a time to urge a requeſt, that during your moſt favourable thoughts of me wou'd have appear'd ſtrange if not preſumptuous. This is the key of my apartment. It contains a ſecret that the exigency of the hour oblig'd me, againſt inclination or propriety, to lodge there. Should Sir Clement return before me, I implore you to prevent his diſcovery, and give to what you find within, your confidence and protection. Lord Gayville—but I ſhall go too far—the moſt anxious event of my life preſſes on me. I conjure you to comply, by all the compaſſion and tenderneſs nature has treaſured in your heart—not for me—but for occaſions worthy their diſplay. Gives the key, which ſhe receives with ſome reluctance, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p:
Heigho! — Its well, he's gone without inſiſting on my anſwer: I was in a ſad flutter of indeciſion. What myſterious means he takes to engage me in a confidence which I could not directly accept!—I am to find a letter, I
—the ſtory of his heart—Its errors and defence—My brother's name, alſo—to furniſh me with a new intereſt in the ſecret, and one I might avow—One may diſlike this art, but muſt be ſenſible of his delicacy.—Ah, when thoſe two qualities unite in a man, I am afraid he is an over-match for the wiſeſt of us—Hark!— ſure that is the ſound of my Uncle's coach — looks out of the window. 'Tis he—and now for the ſecret—Curioſity!—Curioſity! innate irreſiſtible principle in womankind, be my excuſe, before I dare queſtion my mind upon other motives. Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV. Another apartment.
div.p: Oh! lud, I cou'd hardly tremble more at opening this man's apartment, were there a poſſibility of finding him within ſide. How do people find courage to do a wrong thing, when an innocent diſcovery cannot be proſecuted without ſuch timidity.
div.stage: Approaches the door timidly and unlocks it.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Amazement. Miſs Alton! what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alton.
sp.p:
Madam, I was brought here for an hour's concealment; who I really am, I wou'd not, if poſſible to avoid it, divulge in this houſe. When you ſaw me laſt, you honour'd me with a favourable opinion—My ſtory not explained at full, might ſubject me to doubts, that wou'd
ſhake your candour. The circumſtances in which I am involved, are ſtrange, and have ſucceeded with the rapidity and confuſion of a dream— Suffer me to recover for a moment my diſorder'd ſpirits, and I will ſatisfy you farther.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?—She is pale and ready to faint—I cannot let her be expoſed in ſuch a ſituation—Retire—You may rely upon me for preſent ſecurity—You know beſt your pretenſions to my future opinion— hearing Sir Clement begone, or you are diſcover'd— ſhuts her in, and locks Clifford's door.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Oh! the triumph of honour! Oh the ſincerity of friendſhip, how my opinions are ratified—how my ſyſtem is proved.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Oh, ſpirits, ſpirits, forſake me not—oh, for a moment's diſſimulation!

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: There are ſome now who wou'd feed moroſeneſs and miſanthropy with ſuch events; to me they give delight as convictions and warnings to mankind.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Of how ſuperior a quality, my good Uncle muſt be to the benevolence you poſſeſs! it riſes with the progreſs of miſchief; and is gratified (upon principles of general good) by finding confidence abuſed, and eſteem miſplaced. Am I not right in attributing your joy at preſent so that ſort of refinement?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p:
Hah! and to what ſenſations, my good niece, ſhall be attributed the preſent ſtate of your ſpirits? To the diſguſt you took to Clifford almoſt at firſt ſight. It will not be with indifference, but pleaſure, you will hear of his turning
out the verieſt raſcal, the moſt compleat impoſtor, the moſt abandon'd — but hold! hold—I muſt not wrong him by ſuperlatives——he is match'd too.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Really!—I congratulate you upon ſuch a check of charity.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: And I wiſh you joy, my pretty pert one, upon the credit your ſex has acquired, in producing this other Chef-d'ouvre—Such a compoſition of the higheſt vices and the loweſt—

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: I know it will be in vain to oppoſe the pleaſure you take in colouring, by my want of taſte to enjoy it; but you may ſpare your preparatory ſhading, and come to the points with which I am not acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: And pray my incurious niece, with what points are you acquainted?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: That, before Mr. Clifford went abroad, it is ſuſpected his paſſions betray'd him into a fault that muſt be ſhocking to your morality, and that I'm ſure it is not my intention to juſtify. He ought to have reſiſted. It's a ſhame we have not more examples of young men correcting the frailties of womankind—I dare ſay he neglected a fair opportunity of becoming a prodigy.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: I proteſt you have a pretty way of dreſſing up an apology for the venial faults of youth—and it comes with a peculiar grace from a delicate lady of twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p:
Come, Sir; no more of your ſarcaſms. I can treat wrong actions with levity, and yet conſider them with deteſtation. Prudes and pretenders condemn with auſterity. To the collection of ſuſpicions you are maſter of, let me add one—In a young lady of the delicacy—and
age you have deſcribed, always ſuſpect the virtue that does not wear a ſmile.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: And the ſincerity that wears one aukwardly—If you wou'd know the hiſtory of Clifford, aſk but your brother; if of the precious adventurer he has carried off, enquire of Miſs Alſcrip—We ſhall come up with her yet—woe be to any one who harbours her.

sp.speaker: Prompt.
sp.p: Joy to your honour, I ſee you have caught her.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Her!—who?

sp.speaker: Prompt
sp.p: Lady Emily turning. I aſk your ladyſhip's pardon—Having only the glimpſe of a petticoat, and knowing the object of my chaſe was in this houſe, I confeſs I miſtook you.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: In this houſe?

sp.speaker: Prompt.
sp.p: As ſure as we are—She came in thorough the garden, under Mr. Clifford's arm— up the other ſtairs, I ſuppoſe—If my lady had been hereabouts—ſhe muſt have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p: in confuſion. Yes, but unluckily, I was quite out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Such audaciouſneſs paſſes credibility—Emily what do you think of him?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: That he is a monſter aſide. How my dilemmas multiply.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: What, to my houſe! to his apartment here! I wonder he did not aſk for protection in your's — What ſhould you have ſaid?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: I don't know; but, had I been ſo impoſed upon as to receive her, I ſhould ſcorn to betray even the criminal I had engaged to protect.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.p: tries at the door, finds it lock'd. Emily, my dear, do ring the bell to know if the houſekeeper has a ſecond key to this lock.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Prompt.
sp.p: She is certainly there, Sir, and cannot eſcape. Where can ſhe better remain, till you can aſſemble all parties, confront them face to face, and bring every thing that has paſs'd to a full explanation?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: With all my heart; ſend and collect every body concerned as faſt as poſſible— How I long for ſo complicated an exhibition of the purity of the human heart—Come with me, Emily, and help to digeſt my plan—Friends and lovers, what a ſcene ſhall we ſhew you. Takes Lady Emily under the arm. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: YOUR knowledge in the profeſſion, Mr. Rightly, is as queſtionleſs as your integrity; but there is ſomething ſo ſurprizing in the diſcovery of the Charlton eſtate.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: It is ſo ſtrange, that I will not pronounce a poſitive opinion, till I have read again the collateral papers, and conſider'd fully the deſcents in your family. Your grandfather, I think, was deceived in ſuppoſing he had a right to ſell that part of the Charlton eſtate, which Alſcrip propoſes for his daughter's portion. The ſtrength of this old ſettlement muſt have eſcaped my brother lawyer, or he was mad when he put it into my hands.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: If you knew too, how the value of the acquiſition is enhanced, by the opportune moment in which it preſents itſelf—I am in too much emotion to thank you as I ought.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Sir, I want neither compliment, nor acknowledgement, for revealing what I ſhould be a party to diſhoneſty to conceal—but that duty done, wou'd it be an abuſe of benevolence, unworthy as ſome of the parties may be, to preſerve the peace of all concerned.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: In what manner.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p:
Sir Clement Flint will renounce the Alſcrip alliance, at the firſt appearance of this defalcation, and if I am well informed, Lord
Gayville will not lament the loſs of his intended bride. The young lady is therefore free and ſtill poſſeſſed of a great inheritance.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I do not yet perceive what you aim at.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: She has the faults that wealth and a falſe education create, but they are not incurable. Marry her yourſelf. By ſinking the claim in the union with his family, you command the father's approbation; and the daughter muſt be of a ſtrange mould indeed, if the ſame obligation does not become a corrective of her pride, and an excitement to her gratitude. ſmiling I give ſome token of my friendſhip, when, as a lawyer, I propoſe you a wife inſtead of a ſuit in chancery.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I feel all the kindneſs of your ſuggeſtion; but if my claim is precarious, it is as repugnant to my delicacy as to my inclination, to realize it upon ſuch terms; if it is ſubſtantial, I have ſuch a diſpoſition to make—you have a right to all my thoughts; but I have an appointment to obey, that admits no time for explanation; favor me for a moment with your pencil, Rightly takes out a pencil and pocket-book. And a blank page in that memorandum book.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: My life on't, his head is turn'd upon ſome girl not worth a ſhilling——There is an amiable defect, but a very obſervable one in the nature of ſome men. A good head and heart operate as effectually as vice or folly could do to make them improvident.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p:
Mr. Rightly, I confide to your hands a new ſecret relative to the Charlton eſtate; do not read it till you return home, gives the book, aſide
and going. There, Gayville, is one reply to your challenge—and now for another.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: One moment, Sir—I engage for no ſecrecy that my own judgment ſhall not warrant.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: And the benevolence of your heart approve—Thoſe are my conditions.—

div.head: SCENE II. Hyde-Park.
div.stage: Enter Lord Gayville impetuouſly, looking at his watch.
div.p: Not here! I am ſure I marked the hour as well as the place, preciſely in my note, walks about. Had I been told three days ago, that I ſhould have been the appellant in a premeditated duel, I ſhould have thought it an inſult upon my principles—That Clifford ſhould be the cauſe of my tranſgreſſing the legal and ſacred duties, we have ever both maintained—oh, it would have ſeemed a viſionary impoſſibility—But he comes, to cut reflection ſhort—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: I waited for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: That ceremonial would grace an encounter of punctilio, but applies ill to the terms upon which I have call'd you here.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: What terms are thoſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Vengeance! Ample, final vengeance! Draw, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: No, my Lord, my ſword is reſerved for more becoming purpoſes: It is not the inſtrument of paſſion; and has yet been untried in a diſpute with my friend.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: But why is it not ready for a different trial, the vindication of perfidy, the blackeſt ſpecies of perfidy, that ever the malignant enemy of mankind infuſed into the human breaſt—perfidy to the friend who loved and truſted you, and in the neareſt intereſts of his heart.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Take care, my Lord; ſhould my blood boil like your's, and it is riſing faſt, you know not the puniſhment that awaits you. I came temperate, your groſs provocation and thirſt of blood make temperance appear diſgrace—I am tempted to take a revenge—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Draws. The means are ready. Come, Sir, you are to give an example of qualities generally held incompatible — bravery and diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Another ſuch word, and by heaven!— How have I deſerv'd this opinion?

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Aſk your conſcience—Under the maſk of friendſhip you have held a ſecret intercourſe with the woman I adore; you have ſupplanted me in her affections, you have robb'd me of the very charm of my life—can you deny it?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I avow it all.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Unparalleled inſolence of guilt.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Are you ſure there is nothing within the ſcope of poſſibility, that wou'd excuſe or atone—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Death—Death only—no abject ſubmiſſion—no compromiſe for infamy — chuſe inſtantly—and ſave yourſelf from the only ſtretch of baſeneſs left—the invention of a falſehood to palliate —

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p:
In the utmoſt agitation, and drawing his ſword. Falſehood!—You ſhall have no other explanation.
After a ſtruggle within himſelf, Clifford drops the point and expoſes his breaſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Gavyville.
sp.p: Stand upon your defence, Sir— What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: You ſaid nothing but my life wou'd ſatisfy you, take it, and remember me.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: I ſay ſo ſtill—but upon an equal pledge—I am no aſſaſſin.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: with great emotion If to ſtrike at the heart of your friend, more deeply than that poor inſtrument in your hand could do, makes an aſſaſſin, you have been one already.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: That look, that tone, how like to innocence? Had he not avow'd ſuch abominable practices—

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I avow them again: I have rival'd you in the love of the woman you adore—her affections are rivetted to me. I have removed her from your ſight; ſecured her from your recovery—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: I have done it to ſave unguarded beauty; to ſave unprotected innocence; to ſave a ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: A ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: With exultation. Vengeance! Ample, final vengeance! a pauſe It is accompliſh'd— over him—and over myſelf—my victory is compleat.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Where ſhall I hide my ſhame!

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: We'll ſhare it, and forget it here.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Why did you keep the ſecret from me?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p:
I knew it not myſelf, till the ſtrange concurrence of circumſtances, to which you were in part witneſs a few hours ſince, brought it to light. I meant to impart to you the diſcovery,
when my temper took fire—Let us bury our mutual errors in the thought, that we now for life are friends.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Brothers, Clifford—Let us interchange that title and doubly, doubly ratify it. Unite me to your charming ſiſter; accept the hand of Lady Emily in return—her heart I have diſcover'd to be yours—We'll leave the world to the ſordid and the taſteleſs; let an Alſcrip, or, a Sir Clement Flint, wander after the fantom of happineſs, we ſhall find her real retreat, and hold her by the bonds ſhe covets, virtue, love and friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Not a word more, my lord; the bars againſt your propoſal are inſuperable.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: What bars?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Honour! propriety—and pride.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Pride, Clifford?

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord; Harriet Clifford, ſhall not ſteal the hand of a prince; nor will I—tho' doating on Lady Emily, with a paſſion like your own, bear the idea of a clandeſtine union in a family, to whom I am bound by obligation and truſt. Indeed, my lord, without Sir Clement's conſent, you muſt think no more of my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Stern Stoic, but I will, and not clandeſtinely; I'll inſtantly to Sir Clement.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Do not be raſh—Fortune or ſome better agent, is working in wonders—Meet me preſently at your Uncle's; in the mean while promiſe not to ſtir in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: What hope from delay.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Promiſe—

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: I am in a ſtate to catch at ſhadows—I'll try to obey you.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Farewel!— Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir Clement's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Miſs Alſcrip in great ſpirits, followed by Mrs. Blandiſh.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I am delighted at this ſummons from Sir Clement, Blandiſh; poor old clear-ſight, I hope he has projected a reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: How I rejoice to ſee thoſe ſmiles returned to the face that was made for them!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Return'd, Blandiſh? I deſire you will not inſinuate it ever was without them — Why ſure, you would not have the world imagine the temper of an Heireſs of my claſs, was to be ruffled by the loſs of a paltry earl—I have been highly diverted with what has paſſed from beginning to end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Well, if good humour can be a fault, ſure the exceſs you carry it to muſt be the example.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I deſire it may be made known in all companies, that I have done nothing but laugh —nay, it is true too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: My dear creature, of what conſequence is the truth, when you are charging me with the execution of your deſires.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Could any thing be more diverting than my Lord's intriguing with my chambermaid before marriage, that muſt be your cue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: The deſign was in rule, and founded upon the beſt precedents—only the time, in the news-paper phraſe, was premature, he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: And then the airs of the moppet— Could any thing be more ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: The rivalſhip you mean—Rival, Miſs Alſcrip—He! he! he!Half laugh.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Yes, but when you take this tone in public, laugh a little louder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Rival, Miſs Alſcrip, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: wiping her eyes as not quite recovered from her laugh. For mirth's ſake, what is become of the rival? — Who will you chuſe ſhe ſhall have run away with?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Leave it in doubt as it is; fixing circumſtances confines the curioſity to one ſtory which may be diſproved; uncertainty leaves it open to an hundred, and makes them all probable. But I hear ſome of the company upon the ſtairs: Now, Blandiſh—You ſhall be witneſs to the temper and dignity, with which a woman of my conſequence can diſcard a quality courtſhip that offends her—Having ſufficiently mortified the Uncle and Nephew, with a triumphant raillery all my own, I ſhall requeſt Lady Emily to ſet the Paphian mimp upon the family diſappointment, and leave them together to the exerciſe of the patience that uſually attends the loſs of a hundred thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: Sweet temper'd ſoul!

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Miſs Alſcrip, your—

div.stage: As he's beginning to ſay your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: The duel's over, and the combatants in whole ſkins— Never ran ſo faſt ſince I was born—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: —To be too late by ſome minutes in your intelligence. I know you feel the diſappointment from the ſincere affection you bear all parties.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Duel!—Pray let us hear the particulars—As there is no miſchief I ſhall not faint.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: I gueſs it has been of the common place kind.—Hats over the brows—glum ſilence— thruſt— parry—and ripoſte— Explain, and ſhake hands: Your man of honour never ſets his friend right, till he has exchang'd a ſhot—or a thruſt: Oh, a little eſſence of ſteel or gunpowder, is a morning whet to the temper: It carries off all qualms, and leaves the digeſtion free for any thing that is preſented to it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Dear, how fortunate! Conſidering the pills ſome folks have to ſwallow.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Blandiſh, ſee if the door of Clifford's room is yet unlocked, there is a perſon within you little expect to find, and that it may be proper for this lady, and me to interrogate together.— I don't know what to call her—Inexplicability in petticoats. (The door opens) and

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: Lady Emily!

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Inexplicable, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: aſide Lady Emily, ſhut up in Clifford's apartment! Beyond my expectation, indeed. With a malicious air.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: dryly Lady Emily I know you were always cautious whom you viſited, and never gave a better proof of your diſcernment.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Never—oh! my poor dear uncle you little think what is going to befall you.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Not a diſappointment in love, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: No, but in ſomething much nearer your heart—your ſyſtem is threaten'd with a blow, that I think, and from my ſoul I hope, it never will recover: would you gueſs that the ſagacious obſervations of your whole life are upon the point of being confounded by the production—

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: A woman of ingenuous diſcretion, and a man of unaffected intregrity.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: What can ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Nothing good—ſhe looks ſo pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Come forth, my injur'd friend. Our perſonal acquaintance has been ſhort, but our hearts were intimate from the firſt ſight preſenting her Your priſoner, Sir, is Miſs Harriot Clifford.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Clifford's ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: What, the run-away Alton, turned into a ſprig of quality.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: diſdainfully to Miſs Alſcrip. The humble dependant of Alſcrip's houſe—The wanton—the paragon of fraud—the only female that can equal Clifford tauntingly to Sir Clement She is indeed!with emphaſis and affection

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p:
aſide Oh, rot the ſource of the family fondneſs—I ſee I have no card left in my favour—but the Heireſs. Goes to her and pays court.
During this converſation, aſide, Lady
Emily ſeems encouraging Miſs Clifford—Sir Clement muſing, and by turns examining her.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: to himſelf"Ingenuous diſcretion!"

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: My deareſt Harriot! the joy I purpoſed in preſenting you here, is anticipated; but, my blameleſs fugitive! relate the tale of your diſtreſſes, and my pride in you will not be a wonder.

sp.speaker: Miſs Clifford.
sp.p: They have been ſhort—and are overpaid by your indulgence. Inſulted by the family I liv'd with; made more wretched by a deteſted purſuit which my uncle's violence enforc'd, and confident of your being returned, I fled to London for an aſylum.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: Which has been admirably choſen in my houſe.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Sir, I really think ſo. Lady Emily's generoſity, your juſtice, and my ſiſter's honour make it ſacred. While Clifford is ſpeaking

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p:
perceiving Lord Gayville And peculiarly ſecure againſt the viſits of this deteſte •
purſuer.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: with rapture Her perſecutor and her convert. Her virtues which no humility could conceal, and every trial made more reſplendant, diſcover'd, diſgraced, and reclaimed a libertine.

sp.speaker: Miſs Clifford.
sp.p: How am I diſtreſs'd—what ought I to anſwer?

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p:
Impreſſed ſentiment upon deſire, gave honour to paſſion, and drew from my
ſoul a vow, which heaven chaſtiſe me when I violate, to obtain her by a legal, ſacred claim, or renounce fortune, family and friends, and become a ſelf-devoted outcaſt of the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs Clifford.
sp.p: Oh! brother, interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: My Lord, your fortune, family, and friends are much oblig'd to you. Your part is perfect—Mr. Clifford you are call'd upon. Miſs, in ſtrict propriety, throws the buſineſs upon her relations—Come finiſh the comedy; join one of her hands to the gallants, while, with the other, ſhe covers her bluſhes—and he in rapture delivers the moral. All for Love, or, the World well Loſt. Miſs Clifford ſtill appears agitated.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Be patient, my Harriot, this is the ſchool for prejudice, and the leſſon of its ſhame is near.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I vow theſe ſingular circumſtances give me quite a confuſion of pleaſure. The aſtoniſhing good fortune of my late Protegée in finding ſo impaſſion'd a friendſhip in her brother's bed-chamber; the captivating eloquence of Lord Gayville in winding up an eclairciſſement which I admire—not for the firſt time—to day—and the ſuperlative joy, Sir Clement muſt feel at an union, • ounded upon the purity of the paſſions, are ſubjects of ſuch different congratulation, that I hardly know where to begin.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: aſide Charming!—her inſolence will juſtify what ſo ſeldom occurs to one—a ſevere retort without a poſſible ſenſe of compunction.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p:
But in point of fortune—don't imagine, Sir Clement, I wou'd inſinuate that the Lady is deſtitute—oh Lord, far from it. Her
muſical talents are a portion—I can't ſay I have yet ſeen a counteſs open a concert for her own benefit; but there can be no reaſon why a woman of the firſt quality ſhould not be directreſs of the Opera—Indeed, after all that has happen'd, it is the beſt chance I ſee for a good adminiſtration there.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Why ſtop a moment—Mr. Rightly; 'Death after chaſing you all over the town, don't be ſo impatient the inſtant I overtake you.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: What have we here—the lawyers in diſpute?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip
sp.p: entering. You have not heard my laſt word yet.

sp.speaker: Rightly
sp.p: entering. You have heard mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip
sp.p: whiſpering. I'll make the five thouſand I offer'd, ten.

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Millions wou'd not bribe me— coming forward. When I detect wrong, and vindicate the ſufferer, I feel the ſpirit of the Law of England, and the pride of a practitioner.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Lucifer confound ſuch practices. In this part of the ſcene, Sir Clement, Lord Gayville, Lady Emily, Clifford, and Miſs Clifford, form one groupe.

div.stage: Rightly opens a deed, and points out a part of it to Sir Clement.
Mr. and Miſs Alſcrip carry on the following ſpeeches on the ſide at which Alſcrip has enter'd. And Mr. and Mrs. Blandiſh are farther back obſerving.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: That curſed! curſed flaw.—

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Flaw! who has dared to talk of one? not in my reputation, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: No, but in my eſtate, which is a damn'd deal worſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: How! what?—when!—where? —The eſtate that was to be ſettled upon me?

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Yes, but that me, turn'd topſy turvey —when me broke into my room this morning, and the devil followed to fly away with all my faculties at once—I am ruin'd—Let us ſee what you will ſettle upon your poor father.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: I ſettle upon you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: This is an embarraſſing accident.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Yes, and a pretty help you are, with a drop chin like a frontiſpiece to the lamentations.

sp.speaker: Rightly
sp.p: coming forward with Sir Clement. I ſtated this with ſome doubt this morning, but now my credit as a lawyer upon the iſſue.—The Heireſs falls ſhort of the terms in your treaty by two thouſand pounds a year—which this deed, lately and providentially diſcover'd, entails upon the heirs of Sir William Charlton, and conſequently, in right of his mother, upon this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Happy diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.p: aſide. Two thouſand a year to Clifford! It's pity for the parade of diſintereſtedneſs, that he open'd his deſigns upon Emily, before he knew his pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p:
aſide. Now, if there were twenty ceilings, and as many floors, could not I find a ſpot to ſettle my ſilly looks upon.
Sir Clement obſerves her with his uſual ſhyneſs.
Then turning towards Alſcrip Palm a falſe title upon me? I ſhou'd have thought the attempt beyond the collective aſſurance of Weſtminſter-hall—and he takes the loſs as much to heart as if he bought the eſtate with his own money.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip
sp.p: with heſitation. Sir Clement — what think you—of an amicable adjuſtment of all theſe buſineſſes?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.p: ironically. Nothing can be more reaſonable. The value of Miſs Alſcrip's amiable diſpoſition, placed againſt the abatement of her fortune, is a matter of the moſt eaſy computation; and to decide the portion, Mr. Clifford ought to relinquiſh of his acquiſition — Lady Emily—will you be a referée?

sp.speaker: Lady Emily
sp.p: aſide. Yes, the Lynx has me—I thought I ſhould not eſcape— to him. No, Sir; my poor abilities only extend to an amicable endeavour here. to Miſs Alſcrip And really, Miſs Alſcrip, I ſee no reaſon for your being diſpirited, there may be many ready made titles at market, within the reach of your purſe. Or, why ſhould not a woman of your conſequence originate her own ſplendour? there's an old admirer of mine—He wou'd make a very pretty lord—and indeed, wou'd contribute ſomething on his own part to eaſe the purchaſe—The Blandiſh family is well with all adminiſtrations, and a new coronet is always as big again as an old one. I don't ſee how you cou'd lay out part of your independency to more advantage.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh
sp.p: aſide. Yes, but ſince flaws are in faſhion, I ſhall look a little into things before I agree to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: And if you replace this part of your family, pointing to Miſs Clifford by making an humble companion of your old gentleman, I proteſt, I do not ſee any great alteration in your affairs.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip
sp.p: aſide. I'll die before I'll diſcover my vexation—and yet, half crying no title—no place.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Depend upon it, Miſs Alſcrip, your place will be found exactly where it ought to be. The public eye in this country is never long deceiv'd —Believe me—and cheriſh obſcurity—Title may bring forward merits, but it alſo places our defects in horrid relief.

sp.speaker: Miſs Clifford.
sp.p: You ſeem to expect ſomething from me, Miſs Alſcrip—Be in no pain for any thing that has paſs'd between us—My pity has entirely overpower'd my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip.
sp.p: Molly, the ſooner we get out of court the better—we have damnably the worſt of this cauſe, ſo come along Molly taking her under the arm—and farewel to Berkley-ſquare. Whoever wants Alſcrip's houſe, will find it in the neighbourhood of Furnival's-Inn, with the noble title of Scrivener, in capitals —Blank bonds at the windows, and a braſs knocker at the door pulling her. Come along Molly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p:
half crying aſide Oh! the barbarous metamorphoſis—but his fluſterums for a week, will ſerve my temper, as a regimen. I will then take the management of my affairs into my own hands, and break from my cloud anew: and you ſhall find to the company there are thoſe without a coronet, that can be as ſaucy, and as loud, and ſtop the way in all public places as well as the
beſt of you. Lady Emily laughs Yes, Madam, and without borrowing your Ladyſhip's airs.

sp.speaker: Alſcrip
sp.p: pulling her. Come along, Molly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Alſcrip.
sp.p: Oh you have been a jewel of a father. The company laugh.

div.stage: Mr. and Mrs. Blandiſh ſtay behind.

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: aſide What a curſed turn things have taken! My ſchemes evaporate like inflammable air, and down drops poor adventurer.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Mrs. Blandiſh, ſure you do not leave your friend, Miſs Alſcrip, in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: We'll not diſturb the aſhes of the dead—my ſweet Lady Emily—

sp.speaker: Blandiſh.
sp.p: None of your flouriſhes, my dear ſiſter —they already think you a walking dedication— When we can't eſcape a ſituation, the only way is to brave it—So let them tell us we are ſycophants. —be it ſo—then we are the beſt friends ſociety has. Flattery is the diet of good humour, and not one of you can live without it, and when you quarrel with the family of Blandiſh, you leave refin'd cookery to be fed upon ſcraps, by a poor couſin, or a led captain — taking his ſiſter under his arm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Blandiſh.
sp.p: as ſhe goes off Oh the two charming pair. Exit with Blandiſh.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: Precious groupe, fare ye well to Sir Clement. And now, Sir, whatever may be your determinations towards me—here are pretenſions you may patronize without breach of diſcretion. The eſtate which devolves to my friend—

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: To prevent errors, is not his to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement.
sp.p: What now—more flaws?

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: The eſtate was his beyond the reach of controverſy: but before he was truly ſure of it, on his way to Hyde-Park did this ſpendthrift, by a ſtroke of his pen, diveſt himſelf of every ſhilling—Here is the covenant by which he binds himſelf to execute proper conveyances as ſoon as the neceſſary forms can be gone through.

sp.speaker: Lord Gayville.
sp.p: And in favour of whom is this deſperate act?

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: Of a moſt dangerous ſeducer—a little mercenary, that when ſhe gets hold of the heart, does not leave an atom of it our own.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Rightly.
sp.p: with feeling. And there ſhe ſtands; pointing to Miſs Clifford with a look and an emotion that wou' d condemn her before any court in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Emily.
sp.p: Glorious—matchleſs Clifford!

sp.speaker: Miſs Clifford.
sp.p: Brother, this muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.p: Your pardon, my dear Harriet, it is done.
